evidence: Using this approach, many HEAs have been designed, with a single phase Hf 0.5 Nb 0.5 Ta 0.5 Ti 1.5 Zr HEA appearing to offer the best properties. This alloy exhibited a large tensile ductility of ~18.8% and a yield strength of 900 MPa.

microstructure: single BCC phase without any phased transformation or deformation twins. Dislocation slip dominates the severe deformation process.
evidence: the as-cast HfNbTaTiV alloy is in single phase and contains no second phase inclusions or precipitates for strengthening. To further identify the dominant strengthening mechanism against yielding, the microstructure of the alloy after deformation was also examined. Fig.  6  shows the X-ray diffraction pattern and a TEM micrograph of the alloy after deformation to 45% compression. It is evident that the alloy remained in single BCC phase without any phased transformation (Fig.  6(a) ). TEM examination also confirmed that there was no deformation twins within the structure. Dislocation slip dominates the severe deformation process (Fig.  6(b) ).

microstructure: As-cast state; BCC structure; random distribution of the five constituent elements
evidence: The HfNbTaTiV alloy exhibited a high compressive yield strength of 1350 MPa and a compressive ductility of > 45%. It also retained a high yield strength of 720 MPa and ductility of > 35% at 700 C. Such a combination of properties is superior to most known BCC HEAs. The alloy had a similar ductility but a strength 50% higher than the HfNbTaTiZr control alloy.

microstructure: As-cast state; BCC structure; random distribution of the five constituent elements
evidence: The yield strength of the HfNbTaTiZr HEA is estimated to be 𝜎 0.2 cal = 969 MPa, which is also consistent with the experiment.
